metadata.title: Is Michael Jordan the king of low variance? | by Yotam Gafni | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Is Michael Jordan the king of low variance?
metadata.description: “The last dance” brought back Michael Jordan and the whole 80’s-90’s basketball era into our lives. But with it also the neverending debate over who is the “GOAT” or greatest of all times, where…

all_paragraphs: “The last dance” brought back Michael Jordan and the whole 80’s-90’s basketball era into our lives. But with it also the neverending debate over who is the “GOAT” or greatest of all times, where Jordan doesn’t have a clear advantage in the statistics — he didn’t win as many championships as Bill Russell, didn’t score as many points as Kareem, Karl Malone, Wilt Chamberlain and even the still active Lebron James. He dominates points per game but only by a very small margin over Wilt Chamberlain. So what is it that makes him so special? Or is considering him the GOAT just a marketing stunt by NBA promoters and Nike, that got infused in our naive 90s kid's memories? Well, I’d like to consider one last defense that is mentioned repeatedly in the documentary -
He came to win every game, and came to give a big show every game, for that little kid in the audience that never watched him live before.

Maybe we can see this in the data? If Michael Jordan was a consistent performer, we would expect to see that he didn’t have many ‘bad nights’. This means his points per game shouldn’t usually be much lower than his average. The measurement of variance should be able to capture that.

We want to compare Jordan to other great scorers — we will take Kobe Bryant, Larry Bird, Wilt Chamberlain and Lebron James as comparisons. We also want to only take seasons where they scored with good averages, otherwise, the variance comparison is not interesting. Think of it like that — if someone scores an average of five points per game, and never scores more than ten points, this player will have low variance, but he’s no good. We’re looking for the 30 points per game player with variance 5. Also, many players take time to warm up in their rookie years, and have some decline in their final years in the leagues, so we want to leave these out of the analysis. For that purpose, we will only take seasons where the players scored more than 25 on average, and played at least 50 games. We will also show a normalized version of the variance by the average of that season, so that players like Wilt Chamberlain are compensated for seasons with >50 average points per game (how crazy is that..?), that as we mentioned might have inherently higher variance. We will combine regular season with playoffs for the variance estimation. Our data source will be the very detailed https://www.basketball-reference.com
Lebron and Jordan have almost identical variance. Can we craft some finer estimator for consistency?

We don’t want to measure variance in the higher scores — a high variance score punishes a player for having amazing shows of 50–60 points, because it’s very different than his average. We want to only punish for ‘bad nights’, and we want all the players to be measured by some global scale, similar to what we did with the normalized variance, because again if you’re a 5 points player game just measuring distance from your own average wouldn’t count as if you have many bad nights (as your average isn’t so good to begin with). So there you have it. The win definitely doesn’t go to Jordan, but he’s very strong in the consistency category. With the exception of Wilt Chamberlain, I think it will be hard to find players that have similar performances, though that requires much deeper research to verify. Also, of course, scoring isn’t everything — for example, Bill Russel is not a good scorer at all, and Magic Johnson also not so much, and besides other statistics like assists, rebounds, blocks and steals they’re also measured in style, winner attitude and clutch. It’s weird though that you never see second moment statistics used in game analysis, when they are so common in regular statistical work. Basically everything is about averages, and in the best case about conditional expectations (“65% of teams leading 3–1 in the playoffs have …”)
